loans.name: Trương

texts.en:
H. Trương Thị (20203050054) is a 27-year-old female living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children. H. owns & operates a furniture making business where she makes & sells general household furniture to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4.000.000 VND a month.

In 2009, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6.496.000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offering. She is now requesting a new loan of 7.840.000 VND which will be used to purchase tools & other equipment to expand the business. This will be her 3rd loan from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


H. Trương Thị (20203050054) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, H. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các pH. thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ sản xuất & bán trang thiết bị gia dụng thông thường cho các doanh nghiệp và người dân trong cộng đồng địa pH..  H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 4.000.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2009, H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  H. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua nguyên liệu thô bổ sung để mở rộng việc giới thiệu sản phẩm.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.840.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua dụng cụ & thiết bị khác để mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  H. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase tools & other equipment to expand the business

loans.name: Maria Aurora

texts.es:
La señora Maria Aurora S. tiene la edad de 27 años, estudio hasta el tercer grado de secundaria, esta casada y tiene 2 hijos los cuales asisten a la primaria de la comunidad, Doña maria y su familia vienen en la comunidad de El jicaro la cual se caracteriza ser un zona ganadera y se encuentra ubicada en la carretera TierraBlanca- joachin.

Doña maira nos platica que sue esposo trabaja de jornalero en el campo y lo que el gana no lacanza para cubrir los gastos del hogar asi que hace un poco mas de tres años decidio iniciar a trabajar en su propio negocio de cria de cerdos para ayudar a su esposo en los gastos del hogar y los estudios de sus pequeños.

ella nos dice que contruyo un pequeño corral en su casa en el cual cria a sus cerdos. ella los compra desde pequeños cuando solo tienen tres meses, los alimenta y cuida hasta que cresen, cuando estan gordos  y grandes los vende a los carniseros del pueblo o a sus vecionos para las comidas de sus fiestas.

ella necesita este credito para invertirlo en la compra de cerditos, alimento y desparacitantes.

ella nos dice que en un futuro le gustaria agrandar n poco mas su corral o comprar algunos borregos.

Doña maria se encuentra muy agradecida ya que con este credido no solo podra hacer creser su negocio sino tambien darle  sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida
texts.en:
Maria Aurora S. is 27 years old, has a junior high school education, is married, and has two children who attend the local elementary school.  Maria and her family live in El Jicaro, which is characterized as a livestock community located along the Tierra Blanca- Joachin road.

Maria tells us that her husband works as a field hand but does not earn enough to cover the household expenses, so a little over three years ago she decided to start her own business raising hogs to help with the expenses and her children’s tuition.

She tells us that she built a small pen at her house where she raises her pigs.  She buys them as three month old piglets, cares for them, and sells them to the town butchers when they are big and fat.  Her neighbors also buy them for festivities.  She needs this loan to buy more piglets, feed, and anti-parasite medication.

She tells us that she wants to expand her business in the future by adding a second pen and buying some sheep.  Maria is grateful for this loan.  Not only will it allow her to grow her business, but also to give her children a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy piglets

loans.name: La Fortaleza 3 Group

texts.en:
Ana is one of the members of the "L. Fortaleza three " (The Strength three) group, located in the town of Hato Mayor, whose economy depends on farming. Their principal economic activities are the sale of food, clothes, shoes, and accessories. 

Ana is the mother of four children, they live with her as she is a single mother. She tells us that her most difficult challenge is to work hard to proviD. for their well-being. Her favorite activity is to be at home with her children. 

Ana is very moved by receiving her seventh loan from Esperanza Internacional, after having paid off her previous loan satisfactorily and thereby having taken a step towards the growth of her business. She has had her business for around four years. She is planning to invest her new loan in the purchase of jeans, blouses, shirts, t-shirts, and other items. 

She plans to use her profits to save and reinvest in her business. 

The woman in the bottom is part of the group, but was not available when we took the group picture.

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Graciela  es socia del Banco Comunal “3 de Mayo” ubicado en el distrito Ilave, provincia El Collao y departamento de Puno, tiene 53 años de edad, esl madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos.  La señora no cuenta con estudios.
Graciela siempre se ha dedicado a la venta de artículos artesanales como: chalinas, chullos, chales, guantes, bordados en bayeta (tela de la región) y tejido en miniaturas.  Su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que invirtió en su negocio.  Trabaja hace siete años con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos.
Ahora solicitará un nuevo préstamo por la suma de S/. 1300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que invertirá en la compra de bayetas, kiler para pantalón negro y camisa, seis conos de lana de diferentes colores y alphantina de todo color, todo esto para la confección de sus prendas de artesanía, la señora dice que lo vende en Uros Chulluni.  En el negocio la ayuda su hija.
Su sueño es poder exportar los productos ella misma porque dice que prácticamente “los regala a los  vendedores”... “no pagan como debe  de ser, no pagan a su precio”.
Lo que le  gusta del Banco Comunal es la puntualidad y lo que gana el ahorro.
texts.en: Graciela is a member of the community bank "3 de Mayo," located in Ilave, El Collao, Puno, Peru. She is a 53-year-old single mother of two children, and has never had any formal education. Graciela has always worked at selling handmade items: scarves, hats, shawls, gloves, embroidered cloths (made with local fabric), small handkerchiefs, etc. She put her first loan of 300 Soles into her business. Graciela has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for seven years. Now she has requested a new loan of 1300 Soles, which she will use to buy cloth for making shirts and black slacks. She will also buy six skeins of yarn, each in a different colour, an every colour of embroidery thread. She will use all these materials to make handcrafted merchandise, which she will sell in Uros Chulluni. The money she makes through her business also helps her daughter. Graciela's dream is to export her goods on her own terms. At this point, she's practically giving them away to other dealers, who never pay her what things are worth. Graciela's favourite features of her community bank are how quickly things get done, and how much she's able to save.

loans.use: buy cloth, fabric for shirts and slacks, six skeins of coloured wool and embroidery thread of every colour.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is 43 years old and is married with four children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 24,500 Philippine pesos through NWTF to buy items like shampoo and groceries to sell in her sari-sari store.

Merlita has borrowed and repaid 15 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for four years and also earns an income from selling frozen products and from a networking business.

Merlita aspires to save enough money to buy farm land.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The borrower is 35 years old. She is married and has 4 children aged 8, 10, 14, and 18. In 1996, she established her rice business. She started her business because it would help her husband and her family and, also help to build a house on her land. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 700,000 every month. 

She would like a loan of Le 4,000,000 to buy rice - 80 bags @ Le160,000. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000. In the future, she plans to supply to retailers and open another shop. She is very determined and hardworking. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To pay for 80 bags of rice.

loans.name: July

texts.es: July es una mujer trabajadora, tiene 26 años. Junto a su esposo Eloy y sus 2 hijos, viven en una casa alquilada, ubicada en el caserío de San Juan la libertad. El trabajo al que se dedica está laboriosa mujer, es la “agricultura”, hace 5 años que comenzó alquilando un terreno agrícola de 2 hectáreas, pagando anualmente sus alquileres. Con la adquisición de este terreno, inició la siembra de papa y arveja, los que  cuida, fertiliza y cultiva en compañía de su esposo. Los dos venden sus cosechas en el mercado mayorista de la ciudad más cercana a  “Tarma”; pero las semillas de papa los comercializan en el mismo caserío. Además comenta que hace poco incursionó en el negocio de compra y venta de papa al por mayor en el mercado mayorista de la ciudad, donde los días miércoles, viernes y domingo; hay mayor cantidad de personas que compran sus alimentos para la semana. Por lo que aprovecha la demanda generada para obtener un dinero extra. Ahora están trabajando arduamente para poder adquirir sus propios terrenos, y así minimizar costos. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “capital semillera”, y este es el décimo crédito que tiene con MFP, donde espera del apoyo de todos ustedes para continuar con sus planes. Asimismo se compromete en pagar con puntualidad sus cuotas. July de obtener su apoyo, invertirá el dinero solicitado en la compra de varios kilos de papa de diferentes variedades, para implementar su negocio de compra y venta, y si el dinero le alcanza comprará varios sacos de abono orgánico para esparcirlo en sus cultivos de papa.
texts.en:
July is a hard-working, 26 year-old woman.  She lives together with her husband Eloy and her two children, in a rental house, in the small village of San Juan, La Libertad.

This hard-working woman works in 'agriculture'.  She started renting a 2-hectare plot of farmland five years ago, paying the rent yearly.  She started sowing potatoes and peas on the land and she cares for, fertilizes and grows these crops alongside her husband.  The couple sell their harvests in the wholesale market in the nearest town of Tarma.  However, she sells her potato seeds in her own village.  She tells us that a short time ago she also started buying and selling potatoes wholesale in the wholesale market in town.  Wednesdays, Fridays and Sundays are the busiest days as people are buying their food for the week.  She takes advantage of the general demand to make some extra money.  Right now, the couple are working hard so that they can acquire their own farmland and thereby reduce their costs.

July is a member of the "Capital Semillera" community bank and this is her tenth loan from MFP.  She hopes to receive the support of each and every one of you so that she can continue with her plans.  For her part, she pledges to make her repayments punctually.  With your support, July will invest the money she has requested in buying several kilos of different varieties of potatoes to stock her sales business.  If the money stretches far enough, she will also buy several sacks of organic fertilizer to spread over her potato crops.

loans.use: to buy potatoes wholesale and to buy sacks of organic fertilizer

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma has operated a tailoring business for the past eight years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

Fatuma and her husband own a house that has no access to electricity or piped water. Their greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. They have two children, both of whom attend school. 

With the Kshs 15,000 loan she has requested, she wants to purchase cloth materials for tailoring, as well as to buy khangas to offer for sale. She decided to join Yehu in order to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials for tailoring, as well as to buy khangas to offer for sale

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es:
Cecilia, vive con su esposo y sus hijos, ella se dedica a la venta de pupusas, el negocio lo atiende junto a sus hermanas, inician a las 5:00am hasta las 11:00am, de lunes a domingo.

Ella quiere invertir un préstamo en ingredientes, chicharrón, quesillo, aceite, condimentos, también en mejoras a la vivienda, con esta inversión espera tener la capacidad para atender la demanda de los clientes.

Su aspiración es poder mejorar su vivienda, a través del crecimiento del negocio y el aumento en los ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Cecilia lives with her husband and her children. She engages in selling pupusas*. She runs her activity together with her sisters: they start at 5 am and work until 11 am, Mondays to Sundays.
She wants to invest the loan in buying ingredients such as fried pork skin, curd, oil and dressings, as well as in making improvements on her house. She hopes that this loan will help her satisfying her customers’ requests.
Her dream is to succeed in improving her house though the growth of her activity and the increase in her income.

 * A traditional Salvadoran dish maD. of thick, hand-maD. corn tortilla filled with a blend of either cheese, vegetables or meat.

loans.use: To buy fried pork skin, curd, oil and dressing for her activity.

loans.name: Mama Africa Group

texts.en: This is 52 year-old Laina (holding the folder) from Masvingo, a town in south-eastern Zimbabwe. She is married with four children, all attending school.  Laina runs a cross-border retail business selling clothes and shoes. The business has been in operation for 6 years. She says the main challenges faced are high competition from other sellers at the market. Laina has requested a loan of $400 to buy more clothes and shoes to meet demand. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve the living standards of her family. In the future Laina plans to own a shop to sell goods from and to employ workers.

loans.use: to buy clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Bunawona Womens Group

texts.en:
Roze, 43, has been doing well with her food sales business in the last decade. Roze, a buoyant and happily married mother of three, is keen as a mustard about her business, and this may explain the business success she has enjoyed so far.

Roze principally engages in the selling of foods such as maize, bananas and cassava. These sell highly on the food markets. Her auxiliary business is milk sales. 

Her weekly sales income totals up to UGX 150,000, and she intends to use her loan to purchase more food and milk to resell.

For Roze’s group, this is the fourth loan.

loans.use: to purchase more food and milk to resell.

loans.name: Battsend

texts.en:
Battsend, 70, is a pensioner and a farmer. He lives with his two children and his wife on their own small piece of land in Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. He plants certain kinds of vegetables in his backyard. 

His land is located in the track of flooding water, which is always afflicting his fence and vegetable garden. As he is a farmer, it is a big problem which he should solve immediately. In this case, he has decided to build a small flood protection dam on the side where the flood water comes in. If he builds it, it will be not only be an important creation for himself but it will be beneficial for other households as well.
 
Another purpose for his loan is to insulate the walls of his house as his home becomes cold in winter. It is a useful way to reduce the family's firewood usage and is better for the environment. Battsend's loan will be used to purchase some of building materials needed to build the flood protection dam and to insulate his home.

loans.use: to build a flood protection dam and insulate his home.

loans.name: Jumanazar

texts.ru: Жуманазар житель района Шахритус. Ему 55 лет. Он женат. У него семеро детей. Его сын находится в России. Сам Жуманазар занимается разведение мелко - рогатого скота. Этим видом деятельности он занимается два года. Кредит берет для закупа телят. Он хочет расширить свою деятельность.
texts.en: Jumanazar lives in the region of Shahrituz. He is 55 years old, married and has seven children. His son is now working in Russia. Jumanazar breeds small horned cattle. He has been doing this business for two years. He is taking out the loan to buy calves. He also wants to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy calves.

loans.name: Allaoui

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 39 years old, married, and a father to five children, one of whom works. 

Allaoui has owned a shop since 1996, selling spare parts for cars. He has  sufficient experience in this field and a good reputation. He is well known in his area and the surrounding areas. 

He decided to apply for a $2700 loan in order to renovate and redecorate his shop. He aims to make more money to offer him the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: to renovate and redecorate his shop.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 10 years.  He is 43 years old, married to Monica, and they have three school-going children.  

He was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be his sixth loan.  He repaid all his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use the loan amount to buy seedlings and fertilizer.

In future, David hopes to become one of the leading farmers in Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertiliser.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline lives in Changamwe, Kenya and sells clothes, a business she has done for the last two years. She is single and has one child who is four years old and has begun schooling. The area has a high number of both middle and low-income people who form the bulk of her clients.

She has applied for a loan of KSHS 40,000 to help her restock her business with additional clothes in preparation for the December high season. Caroline’s main aim is to grow the business to a boutique shop dealing with new clothes. From this business, her child can obtain better education and good nutrition.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of clothes

loans.name: Danahon's Group

texts.en:
Danahon is the leader of his group. She is 54 years old and is married to a farmer. Together with her husband, she brings up two sons and a daughter. The older son works in Russia, the daughter is a farmer, and the youngest son goes to kindergarten. 

In 2000, with an initial investment of 8000 soms, Danahon purchased four sheep. Since that time she has been engaged in cattle breeding. At the moment, she keeps a cow and calf.  From selling the dairy products and reselling sheep after fattening them, Danahon earns about 5000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, Danahon plans to purchase cattle for breeding. In the near future, she wants to prepare a wedding dowry for the daughter.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Shapanbubu's Group

texts.en:
Shapanbubu is the leader of this group.  She is 58, and together with her husband, who is a retiree, she has raised three sons and six daughters. The youngest daughter and the youngest son study at school. The other children are married and live separately with their own families. In order to earn money to meet their needs, the family breeds livestock and cultivates agricultural products. 

Shapanbubu started this activity about twenty years ago and she got a lot of experience in this business. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase more livestock for breeding, fattening and further reselling. In the future she wishes to improve the family’s welfare.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Evan

texts.en:
Evan is a hard-working married man with three children, living in Hoima, Uganda. He sells soft drinks, rice, and sugar, and has been in this business for 10 years. He is faced with the challenge of price fluctuations and inflation. His business goal is to expand his business into new markets, and his personal goal is to build a permanent home.
Evan needs a loan to buy soft drinks, rice, and sugar for sell during the festive season.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, sugar, and rice for resale.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah, 37, is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has running water and electricity and her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past ten years, Sarah has operated a tailoring business and her customers are her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. Sarah decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

Sarah is requesting a 40,000 KES loan to purchase cloth and material to sell. She dreams of expanding her business in future.

loans.use: to purchase cloth and material

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 30 year old a married woman with five children. Three of them are in school. 

She has had a food stall business in Yambio, South Sudan, for one year.

Grace is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase beans and rice. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase beans and rice for sale.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is a married woman. She has 2 children, ages 20 and 35 years. She describes herself to be a generous woman. She operates a food stall where she sells doughnuts. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located near a school and her primary customers are students. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high price of baking flour. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy an oven. Alice's business goal is to run a big hotel within 5 years.

loans.use: To buy an oven.

loans.name: Dante

texts.en: Dante is a 41-year-old man who lives in the village of San Antonio with his wife and three kids. He is a persevering and very responsible man with a great desire to get ahead every day. For eight years, Dante has run a grocery store in town. He sells mostly food products and manages to earn a significant income, which enables him to provide for his family. His business is the only income for the family. Dante requested a loan of P 10,000 to increase his revenues.

loans.use: to buy drinks, sugar, shampoo and snack foods for her store

loans.name: Nargis

texts.en:
Nargis is a 49-year-old housewife. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. She is a mother of 6 children. Her husband owns a clothing shop in the market, which is the only source of income for the family. He sells a variety of clothes in his shop, which he purchases from various areas. 

Presently Nargis' husband is interested in offering more variety to his customers.  This will help him to increase his net income and savings as well.  However due to the lack of funds, he finds it difficult. Therefore his wife Nargis has requested for a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan so that she can help her husband to purchase a variety of clothes and sell them in the market at profitable prices. With the profit amount her husband wants to grow his business in the future. 

Nargis is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Linah

texts.en:
Hello, lenders. Meet Linah, a 55-year-old farmer from the remote village of Kapsigoria, situated in the Rift valley province of Kenya. The living conditions in this area are tough because there is neither clean water nor electrical connections. 

For 10 years, her primary sources of income have been milk, eggs and horticultural produce. Linah's biggest challenges are disease and a shortage of farm inputs. Farmers in the area lack capital to purchase farm inputs such as chemicals to prevent these diseases. Linah made the decision to join Juhudi Kilimo in order to access loans that would help her improve her farming activities. 

The additional income from the expansion will go to Linah's 8 children's education. With your loan, Linah’s children will acquire a quality education that will act as a strong foundation for a bright future.
This Christmas be inspired and support a Kenyan woman smallholder farmer!

loans.use: to buy seeds and expand her horticulture farm

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is a married woman with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Analiza is 38 years old and has three children who are in school.

Analiza has a fishing business in the Philippines. Analiza requested a PHP 21000 loan amount through NWTF to buy fish nets and other fishing supplies.

Analiza has been in this business for 21 years. In the future, Analiza would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fish nets and other fishing supplies

loans.name: Teu

texts.en:
Teu is married with seven children. She lives in the village of Tafitoala on the south coast of Upolu in Samoa.

Her business activity is plantation and fishing. She grows taro, tamu, bananas, pineapples, yams and vegetables.

Teu is the leader of her village group and is pictured in front of her house. There are 18 women in the lending group and the weekly meeting is held in the house. In fact her house is a complex of buildings. There is the building in the foreground where meetings are held and some members of the family sleep. As can be seen there are no walls which is common in Samoa. If it rains, there are canvas sheets which are rolled down. In the background is a second house or building where other family members live and also eat. There is a wooden kitchen which is located beside this and another traditional Samoan hut which is out of shot. In front of Teu is a lawn area, and immediately behind her can be seen a small garden of flowers. What cant be seen is on either side are grown vegetables and pineapples. Behind the building in the foreground, and between all the houses the ground is covered in small black lava rocks. This is a typical way Samoan houses are surrounded - it is a form of paving. In fact the whole island and in particularly the area of the coast where Tue lives is covered in lava remains.

Although it cannot be seen, Teu\\\'s plantation is at the side and back of the houses in the photo.

As above, Teu is the leader of her village lending group (center chief) and has been a very good ambassodor of the SPBD program

loans.use: Purchase fertiliser, weed killer. Cement for home improvement

loans.name: Gabriel Mbah

texts.en:
Gabriel has two wives and five children. After relocating to settle in his native village, he faced great challenges in providing for his family. This motivated him to join GHAPE and go through all the identified necessary trainings, which included marketing techniques and management organized by GHAPE and sister organizations. With a previous loan he succeeded in providing electronics and wiring services to his community.

Given a loan of $400, he plans to buy electronic spare parts, electrical materials and watch spare parts to continue with repair services and to sell equipment to technician at urban center prices. He plans to pay his loan in 18 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Electronics repairs and household electricity wiring

loans.name: Saidahmad

texts.en: Saidahmad has over 5 years of experience in trading. He began his business by selling  soaps and shampoos. From the beginning he knew that the success of his business depended on the variety of goods he sold. When he heard about  MicroInvest, he became a client and increased the assortment of goods he carried and bought higher quality products. Subsequently, his business became successful and now he has a stream of constant clients. He has 4 children and his dream is to help them get a good education and to meet all their needs.

loans.use: Business development

loans.name: Mich

texts.en: Mrs. Mich T., 48 years old, lives in Kampong Cham and sells vegetable and fruit for a living.  She earns about $2/day in her sales activities and her husband earns $2.5/day working as a teacher.  The couple also supports Mrs. Mich T.'s mother and their 2 children.  This loan will be used to purchase sugarcane and a motorcycle for transporting her product.

loans.use: To purchase sugar cane for her inventory and a motorcycle for her business transportation

loans.name: Mirian Vanesa

texts.es:
Miriam is married and she is 32 ears old. She has two children - the eldest is 8 years old and the youngest is 4 years old. She is expecting her third child. Currently, they all live together. Miriam and her husband support their family with income generated as rural area teachers. Additionally, they run a transportation company and a small store in their neighborhood. Their transportation business serves the LA BELGICA-WARNES-LA BELGICA loop. Rented motorcycles are used to take passengers due to its swiftness and fuel efficiency. There is a fair amount of competition in the area, but thanks to high demand, its impact is not felt. The loan being sought will be used to pay for the repair of a larger vehicle used for bigger hauls. Miriam's credit history demonstrates that she has timely and responsibly made her payments .

Translated from Spanish by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer

Miriam es una señora casada de 32 años de edad, es madre de dos hijos, el mayor tiene 8 años y la segunda tiene 4 añitos, actualmente esta esperando el tercer hijo. Todos actualmente viven juntos, Miriam y su esposo sustentan a su familia con los ingresos que le generan sus sueldos de profesores rurales. Adicionalmente se dedican al transporte y a la atención de una pequeña tienda de barrio. Respecto al negocio de transporte hacen los tramos de LA BELGICA-WARNES-LA BELGICA, también tienen motos que rentan todos los días, esto debido a que el medio de transporte preferido en estas zonas es la motocicleta por su ahorro en combustible y practicidad. La competencia en los diferentes rubros es media, pero la misma no afecta mucho ya que la demanda es bastante elevada. El presente crédito es para reparar el motor de uno de sus vehículos que utilizan para hacer los transportes grandes. El historial crediticio de Miriam es bueno ya que siempre cumplio sus obligaciones de manera puntual y responsable.

loans.use: Reparación del motor de su movilidad

loans.name: Akbar

texts.en:
I. Akbar is a young and pleasant businessman. He has run his own food shop in Khujand for over 8 years. During these years, he has become a skillful salesman and is always ready to meet all clients' needs. He is very polite with clients and carefully takes their orders. He has a wide assortment of goods and his food products are of high quality. Today his shop is one of the better-known shops in the area. He is one of Microinvest's more active clients and repays his loans on time.

Akbar is married and has one child. His wife is a housewife and is fond of raising their young child. Akbar tries to meet all of his family's needs and to create comfortable living conditions for them. He hopes to open a trading stall or space in the center market in Khujand. For this purpose, he is seeking a loan with which to expand his business and save money for the new trading stall.

loans.use: To open a trading stall/ space in the centre of Khujand.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is 29 years old and married with 3 children. Two of her chiildren are in school and she has a baby of one year.

Rosalina started her chicken farm business when she joined the SPBD programme in 2005. She has since paid off her first loan. She has not needed a new loan because of the good income she has generated from her chicken farm so far. However, she has just rejoined SPBD because she wants to expand her business. She is seeking this loan to buy wires and other supplies for her poultry farm. Her husband helps her with this business, and also works a taro plantation to earn extra money. He sells the produce from the plantation every two weeks. Rosalina earns $180 WST ($72 USD) a week from the poultry farm and $150 WST ($60 USD) from the taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her poultry farm

loans.name: Zoraida Victoria's Group

texts.en:
Zoraida, Cristina, and Paulina have been members of the community bank Glorioso for the past 7, 2, and 3 years respectively. In that time they have learned to be responsible and punctual, and to save. They have also learned the importance of self-esteem.

Zoraida is 38; she is married and has two children. She runs a well-stocked grocery store where she sells food staples, clothing, and cosmetics. Furthermore, Zoraida has computers available for Internet use. Cristina is 64 years old; she is married and has three children, only one of whom lives with her. Cristina has been selling food staples from her house for the past 10 years. Paulina is married and has four children; she is 58 years old. Paulina has a small grocery store in the Capillapata neighborhood.

Zoraida, Cristina, and Paulina need loans of 1600, 600 and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy rice, sugar, oil, milk, beans, soap, detergents, soft drinks, beer, pre-paid phone cards, tuna fish, cookies, candies and chocolates.

They plan to use their savings to increase the capital of their businesses, to educate their children, and for unexpected costs. Zoraida, Cristina, and Paulina dream of owning a large grocery store, improving their homes, and that their children will be professionals.

loans.use: Zoraida, Cristina, and Paulina need loans of 1600, 600 and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy rice, sugar, oil, milk, beans, soap, detergents, soft drinks, beer, pre-paid phone cards, tuna fish, cookies, candies and chocolates.

loans.name: Phat

texts.en: Mrs. Phat P. K., 33, works as a tailor, earning an average profit of $2 each day.  She is a widow and lives with her parents in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia. Mrs. Phat P. is requesting a loan to purchase threads and clothing for her business.  The remainder of the loan will be used to assist in the building of her house.

loans.use: To purchase threads and clothing for her business; the rest of the loan will be used to assist in the construction of her house.

loans.name: Gilma

texts.es:
Señora Gilma belongs to the communal bank “Juntas Hasta el Final”, located in Jr. Zarumilla 150, in the district of Calleria, and in the Department of Ucayali. She is 32 years of age and is single.

Presently she has a business of selling soft drinks, goodies, and also sells used clothes. Each month goes on two business trips to different communities on the Ucayali river. The income that her business provides her with is good.

With a loan of 1,700 Soles, which she will repay in 5 months, she will invest it in purchasing used clothing and snack foods to sell.

In general, Gilma feels very happy, she business is going well and she hopes to that it will continue to grow so that she will be able to live a calm and worry-free life.

Translated from Spanish by Johnny of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Gilma pertenece al Banco Comunal Juntas Hasta el Final, ubicado en el Jr. Zarumilla 150, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 32 años es soltera.

En la actualidad tiene un negocio de venta de gaseosas y golosinas, y también vende ropa usada, cada mes realiza dos viajes a los diferentes caseríos del rió Ucayali, pero sin descuidar su otro negocio que también le da muy buenos ingresos.

Con este préstamo recibido de S/. 1,700, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, lo invertirá en la compra fr ropa usada, y golosinas en general

Gilma se siente muy contenta, sus negocios van bien y espera que para el futuro crezcan mas y así poder llevar una vida tranquila sin preocupaciones

loans.use: buying products liked used clothing and snacks

loans.name: Orlando

texts.es:
.Orlando is a public service chauffeur “Inter – Ciudad La Paz El Alto”, he owns a vehicle and transports passengers, but the vehicle is not in perfect condition and the problems may intensify in the future. His wife works half-time as a domestic servant and she helps economically by covering the maintenance of their two children, 4 years and 9 months old. They do not own a house but rent in the Zona Pasankeri of the City of La Paz. The loan requested by Orlando will be used to buy a new motor to improve the performance of his vehicle (work tool). This is his first loan with Impro, and the evaluation made approves him for the loan requested.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Orlando es chofer de servicio publico Inter – Ciudad La Paz El Alto; tiene su movilidad con la cual trabaja como transporte de pasajeros y no se encuentra en perfecto estado y tiene problemas que pueden agudizarse en el futuro; la esposa trabaja medio tiempo de empleada domestica, y ayuda a los ingresos de la familia para cubrir la manutención de sus dos hijos de 4 años y 9 meses. No cuentan con casa propia y viven en alquiler en la Zona Pasankeri de la Ciudad de La Paz. El crédito que ahora Orlando solicita es para comprar un nuevo motor que le ayudará a mejorar el rendimiento de su movilidad (herramienta de trabajo). Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada permite aprobarle el préstamo solicitada por el prestatario.

loans.use: Purchase a new motor for a public transportation vehicle.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana K. is a fifty-two-year-old divorced mother of three children. Her children have benefited a lot since her husband divorced her.

Diana sells maize and cassava, which are two major staple foods in Ghana. She has been selling these commodities for the last fourteen years. She is not able to buy larger quantities of the goods due to low capital. However, Diana believes in the help that a loan can provide. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of maize for keep, especially in the face of increasing food prices due to the current food crisis. This, she hopes, will increase her income to sponsor her last child in apprenticeship.

She is a member of the community group called Christ Nti Trust Group. Members act as social collateral for one another to guarantee the loans for each other.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize to store.

loans.name: Rachna

texts.en:
Mrs. Rachna B., age 38, and her husband, Mr. Khan Preab, age 39, who live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1992 and have 4 children: 2 sons and 2 daughters. One of their daughters weaves silk at home and the others are in school.

Mrs. Rachna has been a silk weaver for 20 years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh, while Mr. Khan has been a ferry-boat repairer for 3 years.

Mrs. Rachna is requesting a loan of $250 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: María Soledad

texts.es:
Maria is a 54 year old woman, born in 1953 in the province of Yunguyo and she managed to study up to the third graD. of secondary school. She is married, and has 8 children, 4 boys and 4 girls, who are all studying at different levels. She has her own house with complete basic services.

From when she was very young, Maria learnt from her mother how to make empanadas. She travelled, for reasons for work, to Lima, where she put even more effort into this activity. Then, on returning to her hometown, she didn't hesitate to set-up a Snack Bark, where she offers sandwiches, cakes, empanadas and a special fixed meal.

She is a member of the Community Bank, ““Wiñay Marca” , where she started with a loan of 300 soles, purchasing the ingredients needed to make empanadas such as flour, fat, eggs and sugar.

With this loan of 1000 soles, which will be repaid within 4 months, she will buy rice, flour, fat, sugar, vegetables and potatoes wholesale. In this manner she will be able to expand her production.

Being a bank member has taught her to be reliable, responsible and organised in her business, and as a result she's very happy. Her future ambitions are that all her children become professionals and work. She will continue working in her business, as she can depend on her husband's help.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

María es una señora D. 54 años D. edad, nació en el año 1953 en la provincia D. Yunguyo y logró estudiar hasta el tercer grado D. secundaria, se casó tiene 8 hijos cuatro varones cuatro mujeres quienes están estudiando en diferentes niveles D. estudio, tiene una casa propia con los servicios básicos completos.

Ella desD. muy joven aprendió la elaboración D. empanadas D. parte D. su madre, viajo por motivos D. trabajo a la ciudad D. Lima, donD. puso mas empeño a esa actividad; pues al regresar a su tierra natal no dudó en instalar una Snack Bar, en donD. se atienD. desD. bocaditos, alfajores, empanadas y menú especial.

Es socia del Banco Comunal “Wiñay Marca” donD. inicio con un crédito D. S/. 300.00, comprando productos para la elaboración D. empanadas como harina, manteca, huevos y azúcar.

Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,000.00, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará arroz, harina, manteca, azúcar, verduras y papa al por mayor. D. esa manera incrementará su producción.

Siendo socia del banco comunal aprendió a ser cumplida, responsable y organizada en su negocio, por lo que esta muy contenta. La visión futura que tiene es que todos sus hijos sean profesionales y trabajen. Seguir trabajando en su negocio, para ella cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposo.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients wholesale

loans.name: Juana Mercedes

texts.es:
Juana B. lives in the Ticuantepe municipality which is known for its pineapple and pitahaya (cactus fruits) harvests. Juana has been growing pitahayas for the past 20 years. She has 4 children who are married and independent. Juana’s life partner is also in the farming business and both support each other in the harvest. On occasion, he also works as a bricklayer when the harvests do not generate income. Juana also has a small business selling candies from her home. The loan she is requesting will be used to purchase fertilizer to improve the pitahaya and to obtain better harvests.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

Juana B. habita en el municipio de Ticuantepe conocido por sus cosechas de piña y pitahayas. Y uno de esos agricultores es Juana, tiene 20 años de dedicarse al cultivo de pitahayas. Juana tiene 4 hijos, ya todos están casados y son independientes a ella. El compañero de vida de Juana también es agricultor y ambos se apoyan en el trabajo de la cosecha. Aunque también en ocasiones el trabaja como albañil, para buscar maneras de subsistencia mientras la cosecha no genera ingresos. Juana también tiene una pequeña venta de golosinas en su casa de habitación. El crédito será usado para la compra de abono para mejorar la pitahaya y tener mejores cosechas.

loans.use: Fertilizer for her crop.

loans.name: Emilio

texts.es:
Emilio vive en la calle Portocarrero  de la zona Franz Tamayo en la ciudad de El Alto. Tiene esposa y dos hijos. 
Se dedica al transporte publico en su minibús durante toda la semana.

El crédito lo destinara en la compra de repuestos para su vehiculo.  
 
Es su primer  crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica óptimamente.
texts.en:
Emilio lives on Portocarrero Street, in the Franz Tamayo zone, in the city of El Alto. He has a wife and two children. He uses his minibus for public transportation during the whole week. This loan will be used to buy spare parts for his vehicle. This is his first loan with Impro. The assessment carried out rated him optimally.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maintenance of his vehicle

loans.name: Cirilo

texts.es:
El Sr. Cirilo tiene un negocio de venta de tacos desde hace ya más de 6 años  su ubicación donde el vende es  cerca de su casa a fueras de una escuela. 
 El Sr. Cirilo esta solicitando un préstamo de $1,000.00 dlls para comprar mas inventario a su negocio y así preparar diferentes guisados para las tacos y también tener mas variedad de comidas para vender; Así su negocio va a crecerá más en ventas ya que es la fuente de ingreso de se familia. 
Cirilo ya a tenido crédito con Fvp y con Kiva este seria su segundo crédito
texts.en:
Mr. Cirilo has had a business selling tacos for over 6 years now. The location of his business is close to his house, outside of a school.

Mr. Cirilo is requesting a loan for $1,000.00 to buy more inventory for his business and in that way prepare different stews for his tacos and also have more variety of meals to sell. This will allow his business to grow more in sales, since it is the source of income to his family.

Cirilo has had loans with Fvp and with Kiva this would be his second loan.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying inventory

loans.name: Savun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savun C., 49, and her husband, Mr. Chhorn Kek, 45, married in 1978. They have ten children, four sons and six daughters. Five of their children are married and live outside of the family home and the other five children study at the local school. The family lives along National Road Number Six about twenty Kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Savun and her husband have been farming for thirty years. They sell their yield to the middleman in the village. Besides farming, Chhorn also fishes. Savun is requesting a loan of $250 to purchase fertilizer, pesticides and rice seeds.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pesticides, rice seeds.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella O. sells medicines in her store. She is 39 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Her children are both in primary and secondary school. Stella purchases medicines from Onitsha to sell in Benin City. She has good relationships with her customers and this has helped her business. She requests a $425 loan to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Thary Hour Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eight people who live in Pou Kraom village in Kandal Province make up this village bank loan. They will use the loan for a variety of purposes.

Mrs. Thary H. is the village bank president and she is a vegetable seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Hok Sang, is a vegetable farmer. In his plantation, he now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to purchase fertilizers to make his crop more productive. Thus, Mrs. Thary H. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers for her husband's plantation. Mrs. Thary H. is 27 years old and the mother of two children who are aged three and five years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for a vegetable plantation.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana is the mother of four exciting children.  Her business is a "comedor" (restaurant) that serves Dominican food.  She supports her family with her income.  The "comedor" also allows her to work from home and take care of the children.  With this loan, Ana will build a bathroom in the house for the family.  Please proviD. dignity and privacy for this wonderful family!  Thank you!

loans.use: Bathroom

loans.name: Milena

texts.es:
La señora Milena, pertenece al Banco Comunal “LAS TRIUNFADORAS”, ubicado en el Jr. Salaverry N° 845, Distrito de Callería, tiene 52 años de edad su esposo es comerciante, ella apertura un restaurante donde vende productos naturales, ella es socia hace 3 años de Manuela Ramos.
El primer préstamo que recibió fue de S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, con los cuales compró: arroz 25kg, azúcar 25kg, aceite 06 unidades de 01 litro, especierías, carne roja 03kg, pollos 02; se inicio vendiendo menú variado, entre ello vegetariano.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1, 700.00  Nuevos Soles, compró 06 sacos de arroz, azúcar  02 sacos, aceite 02 docenas, 20kg de fideos, 50kg de carne roja, compra 05 pollos diarios, frutas, pescados, verduras, se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus compras y atender a  sus clientes desde las 7:00 am de la mañana con la ayuda de su esposo  y  su personal. 
Esta muy Agradecida de Manuela Ramos por su confianza en ella, que siga apoyando a muchas mujeres que desean trabajar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Milena participates with the Banco Comunal (communal bank) "Las Triunfadoras" located on Jr. Salaverry N° 845 in the Callería. She is 52 years old. Her husband is a trader. She has a restaurant where she sells natural products. She's been Manuela Ramos' partner for three years. The first loan Mrs. Milena recieved was for $300 Nuevos Soles that she used to bue 25kg of rice, 25kg of sugar, 6 liters of oil, spices, 3kg of red meat, and 2kg of chicken. She began with a varied menu that included vegetarian dishes. With this new $1700 Nuevos Soles loan, she will buy 6 bags of rice, 2 bags of sugar, 24 liters of oil, 20kg of noodles, 50kg of meat, 5 chickens every day, fruits, fish and vegetables. She gets up very early to make her purchases and she attends her customers since 7 a.m. with her husband and staff's help. She is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for her trust. She hopes she will continue to support more women who wish to work.

Translated from Spanish by Jonathan Bradshaw, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 6 bags of rice, 2 bags of sugar, 24 liters of oil, 20kg of noodles, 50kg of red meat, 5 chickens daily, fruits, fish, vegetables

loans.name: Tamate

texts.en:
Tamate L., 19, is married with one child. She just started selling bananas and taro and also plants and harvests them. She sells to the Fugalei market and general public five days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner.

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (about $104). SPBD loans are Tamate’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. This loan will be used to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy pesticides, chemicals, insect killer and to replace some planting equipment

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Lucila es socia del Bancomunal Amigas Unidas.
Lucila es conviviente tiene 49 años, dos hijos de 14 y 12 años que están en la escuela estatal.
Lucila siempre se dedico a su casa y al cuidado de su familia, pero hace cinco años la visitó una consultora de belleza y la animo a vender, explicándole el sistema de ventas le gusto y decidió vender productos de belleza por catalogo, actualmente lleva los productos a diferentes empresas y ofrece a sus amigas.  
Lucila necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para la compra de productos de belleza por catalogo.
Desde que está en Finca, ve que es un respaldo para invertir en su mercadería.  
El sueño de Lucila es suplir todas las necesidades de sus hijos, y tener un negocio,
texts.en:
Lucila is a member of the Communal Bank "Amigas Unidas" (United Friends). Lucila lives with her husband and she is 49 years old. She has two children who are 14 and 12 years old. They both go to public schools. Lucila has always worked hard to keep her home nice and to take care of her family. Five years ago she decided to visit a beauty consultant and the consultant told Lucila about how great it would be if she started selling beauty products. The consultant explained the system of sales and Lucila liked it. She decided to sell beauty products through catalogues. At the moment she takes products to different companies and also offers the products directly to her friends. Lucila needs a loan $325 (1000 Soles), so that she can buy beauty products out of catalogues to sell. Ever since Lucila has been in the group Finca she has seen that investing money in purchasing more merchandise has helped her to grow her business. Lucila's dream, is to fulfill all the needs of her children and to have her own business.

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Lucila needs a loan $325 so that she can buy beauty products out of catalogues to sell.

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Le  groupe Jiguisseme est composé de 6  femmes  toutes mariées qui ont en moyenne  36 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des  familles polygames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers populaires de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de fruits, de pomme de terre, de  poisson fumé et la restauration.
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin croissant de leur clientèle et d’augmenter leur revenu elles ont décidé de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire. Les précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Avec ce  prêt, elles comptent acheter, 100 régimes de banane, 300 kg de pomme terre, 15 colis de condiments, 400 kg de riz pour la restauration et 15 cartons de poisson fumé. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Médine, dans les villages environnants et au grand marché de Sikasso 
La plupart des marchandises sont vendues au comptant à la foire, dans les familles de  façon ambulante à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 14 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Jiguisseme ambitionnent de pérenniser leur collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso  pour devenir des clientes individuelles.
texts.en:
This Jiguisseme group is made up of 6 married women who have an average age of 36, 4 children, and live in polygamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the working class neighborhoods of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali.

They have various businesses, among others selling fruit, potatoes, smoked fish, and cooked food. With the intention of satisfying the growing needs of their clientele and increasing their earnings, they decided to work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 6th solidarity loan. The preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan they intend to buy 100 stalks of bananas, 300 kg of potatoes, 15 packets of condiments, 400 kg of rice to cook and sell, and 15 cases of smoked fish. They buy their supplies at the market of Médine, in the surrounding villages, and in the big open-air market in Sikasso.

Most of the merchandise is sold for cash at the weekly market and to families door-to-door, to a clientele composed of men and women. They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 14,000 F CFA, of which part will be used for family needs, and the rest reinvested into their businesses.

The women of this Jiguisseme group hope to continue their group collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso for a long time, so as to become individual clients.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo sells provisions and foodstuffs. She started this business eight years ago. She hopes for the loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She is 33 years old and married to F. who sells motor spare parts, and they have a child. She says thank you, and promises to pay back her loan promptly

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Juan Sebastian

texts.es: El Sr. Juan Sebastian Cuariti, trabaja con su mamá la Sra. Joaquina, quien fue cliente anteriormente, pero por su enfermedad, quien se hace cargo de los trabajos es el hijo, razón por la cual, el destino del crédito es para compra de materia prima, ellos tienen una tienda llamada Creaciones Santa Lucía, donde realizan la costura bordada a mano de vestidos de niñas, a la vez también reciben pedidos para confecciones de ropa de niñas, él es cliente hace un año, pero la mamá  trabajo con Emprender más de seis años, demostranso cumplimiento.
texts.en:
Juan Sebastian Cuariti works with his mother Joaquina who had previously been the loan client, however, due to her illness her son now is in charge of the business. This loan will be used to purchase basic materials; they own a store named “Creaciones Santa Lucia” where they make hand-sown girls dresses and also take orders to make girls clothing. He has been a bank member for the past year, but his mother has worked with Emprender for over six years, always fulfilling her commitments.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fabrics to make girls clothing.

loans.name: Setra Bagam Group

texts.en: This is the Setra Bagam group, which is led by Setra Bagam. There are three members in this group. Each of the members wants to take a loan for his or her business. Setra Bagam wants to take a loan on behalf of her husband for his general store. Asmatullah also wants to take a loan for his general store. Mayku wants to take a loan on behalf of her brother for his vegetable and fruit shop. They are requesting a group loan 30,000 afghani. They are very happy for this loan opportunity in Afghanistan.

loans.use: For expanding general store

loans.name: Mr. Yoen Khem Village Bank Group

texts.en: Twenty-two people who all live in Khsom village in Kandal province make up the village bank and they will use the loan in different ways. Mr. Y. K. is the village bank president. He has been selected by the members. Mr. Y. K. is a fisherman who can catch a little fish for his living. In his business, he now faces a small problem because his boat is too old and it cannot go to catch the fish; thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy a boat for this purpose. His wife, Mrs. Yom Keop, is conducting a firewood cutting business. They try to help each other in order to improve their living conditions. Mr. Y. K. has six children who are all working in different businesses.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat

loans.name: 01-Đông Hải Group

texts.en:
Liên T. Thị is 39 and lives in the town of Thanh Hoá.  Liên is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 01-Đông Hải (16-03-001).

Liên is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Liên raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Liên has been engaged in this business for more than 25 years and earns approximately 1500000 Vietnamese dong (approximately $84) a month from these activities.

In 2004, Liên joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liên has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3079800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. She is now requesting a new loan of 6000000 VND, which will also be used to purchase fertilizer. The loan will be the tenth  taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Liên plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  N. Thị Tâm, 47, is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising crops.

2.  Lê Thị Hồng, 25, is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising crops.

3.  N. Thị Hoan, 51, is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising crops.

4.  Lê Thị Nhật, 51, is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising crops.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Liên T. Thị (19) là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Liên là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 01-Đông Hải (16-03-001).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ trồng & thu hoạch gạo để bán.  Liên thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 25 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Liên kiếm được khoảng 1500000 VND.  Vào 2004, Liên đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Liên đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua phân bón như phân chuồng.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 10th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. Thị Tâm (21) là 47 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực.


2.  Lê Thị Hồng (104) là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực.


3.  N. Thị Hoan (22) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực.


4.  Lê Thị Nhật (105) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Hugo Alberto

texts.es:
El señor Hugo Alberto no aparece en la fotografía en representación sale su esposa la señora María Guadalupe Bran Tovar.
Esta familia tiene un negocio de abarrotes desde hace 6 años llamado “Gaby”, con lo ingresos de este ellos pagan las colegiaturas de su hijo que esta en universidad privada  y las mensualidades son muy altas. Ellos quieren dejarle un buen estudio a sus hijos para que se defiendan en un futuro.
Pero el crédito es para surtirse de mercancía en este negocio, para mayor ganancias, aunque ellos trabajan en maquiladora los dos trabajan en horarios distintos para atender la tienda.
texts.en:
Hugo Alberto is not in the photograph. His wife, María Guadalupe Bran Tovar, is in the photograph representing him. This family has had a grocery business named Gaby for six years. They are paying the educational fees for their son with the income from the business. He is in a private university, and the monthly fees are very high. They want to give their children a good education so that they can take care of themselves in the future. The loan is to stock merchandise in their business in order to get more earnings. Both of them work in a factory. They work different shifts in order to take care of the store.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock the business

loans.name: Anasoronye

texts.en: Anasoronye, 43 years old and married with six children, sells secondhand clothes. She is requesting the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma Z., 60, is from the village of San Isidro, Medina Misamis Oriental. She is married and has six adult children. Thelma owns a retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of products like vinegar and soy sauce. Thelma has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In June 2009, Thelma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thelma is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Thelma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Obaapa Group

texts.en: Felicia is forty-six years old. She is divorced and has give birth to four children, all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Felicia is a trader. She trades in footwear. She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Obaapa’, meaning a virtuous woman. The group members are engaged either in farming and/or trading activities. They sell/supply in their local market and nearby communities. They sometimes trek to nearby community markets. They want a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en:
JamA. is a 28-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children.

JamA. has been working as a car repairer and painter for a few years now. He requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools, a compressor and paint for his work. This is his fourth loan and he has always repaid on time.

JamA.’s previous loans helped him improve and adapt himself with the required tools for his work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his work, he had some financiA. issues. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools, a compressor and paint

loans.name: Pamela Awuor

texts.en:
Pamela Awour operates a shop and photocopy services in Manyatta, a low-income settlement on the outskirts of Kisumu City. She is 45 years old and the mother of two. The income from her business has enabled her to pay for her living expenses and send her children to school. Pamela has been in her business for three years.

This is Pamela's third loan from KADET Ltd. and she plans to use the funds to increase her stock in readiness for the approaching school closure and holidays – a period during which she hopes to increase her sales judging by the trends her business goes through annually. She hopes to open a wholesale outlet to be able to serve the community better while increasing her income levels.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her general store and photocopy services business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of cloth and tailoring accessories

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 40-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their five children. Ibrahim has been working as a builder since 1992. Ibrahim requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time. 
Ibrahim is special in his work because he does it well. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had some financial issues. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work and he had experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: Seun

texts.en: Seun sells baby cream and clothes at retail prices. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She hopes to own a boutique for children in the future. She is married with 2 children. Her eldest child is a boy and he is 4 years old. The youngest child is a girl and she is one year old. Seun is 29 years old. She is carrying her youngest child in the picture. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more baby cream and clothes to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby cream and clothes to sell

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en: Rosemarie has an agricultural business in Banga, South Cotabato. Now at the age of 43, she manages a corn field that is 2 hectares. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to request a loan of 8,000 Php to support her business. She is a mother of 5 children. She wants to improve her business in order to support her family. This loan will be very helpful to finance her business with a low interest.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Aracely

texts.es: Aracely R. H. de 43 años de edad, reside en San Juan Opico, departamento de La Libertad. Vive junto a su esposo  sus dos hijos. Ella posee un taller de confección de ropa para hombre, mujeres y niños, la cual la comercializa en su hogar o de manera ambulante. Así mismo se encarga de trabajar por pedidos, lo cual es lo más usual en su forma de trabajo. Aracely es una persona que se destaca por ser muy trabajadora y muy responsable la cual realiza su trabajo a tiempo y así mismo desempeña una labor excelente, razón por la cual las personas la prefieren. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar repuestos para la maquina de coser, así mismo para poder comprar mayor cantidad de tela, hilos y botones. Para Aracely el hecho de mejorar sus ganancias la incentiva mucho ya que para ella es vital brindarle ayuda económica a su esposo con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Aracely R. H. is 43 years old and lives in San Juan Opico, in the Departament of La Libertad, El Salvador. She lives with her husband and her two children. She has a workshop where she makes clothing for men, women and children, which she sells from her home or door to door. She also works to order, which is quite typical in her line of work. Aracely is someone who distinguishes herself with her hard work and responsibility. She finishes her work on time and also does an excellent job, which is why people prefer her work. She is asking for a loan through which she can buy replacement parts for her sewing machine, and also to be able to buy more cloth, thread and buttons. For Aracely the opportunity to improve her earnings is a great incentive, because it is vital for her to offer her husband help paying the household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cloth, thread and buttons.

location.town: San Juan Opico, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Los Agachados Group

texts.es: El grupo  “Los Agachados ” esta representado por el señor Hugo Jesús y conformado por 12 miembros que empiezan un primer ciclo con entusiasmo y ganas D. trabajar, todos se conocen y se tienen confianza debido a que son D. la misma zona. Entre las actividades que realizan podemos mencionar la venta D. Pan, comida, cerveza, ropa y al servicio D. soldadura, transporte público y la enseñanza en escuelas. Dentro del ámbito comercial siempre existe la competencia por lo que las socias no son la excepción, muchas D. ellas deben esforzarse mucho más que sus compañeras para obtener un ingreso razonable para cumplir con sus obligaciones y con sus familias. El destino del financiamiento es para la compra D. insumos, materiales y herramientas que ayuden a mejorar sus ventas y por enD. mejorar mas sus ingresos para poder darles a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida. Entre sus expectativas esta mejorar sus ventas con una mejor mercadería y poder darles a sus hijos una educación universitaria y un hogar fijo ya que una gran mayoría D. las socias no posee casa propia. En general las socias conocen el producto y la forma D. trabajar bajo la modalidad D. créditos solidarios ya que muchas D. ellas trabajaron con instituciones que también cuentan con este servicio, pero están satisfechos con el trato que les da la fundación a la cual agradecen por su  apoyo económico y su confianza.
texts.en:
The group “Los Agachados ” is led by Sr. Hugo Jesús and consists of twelve members who are starting their first loan cycle with enthusiasm and a willingness to work. All of them know and trust each other because they are from the same area.
